When Lyndon Johnson was growing up, Johnson City had no electricity, a common occurrence at that time in most rural areas around the United States. People relied on kerosene lanterns for lighting, and on windmills, horses, and the occasional gasoline motor for other jobs that were too difficult to be performed by hand. In 1935, President Franklin Roosevelt created the Rural Electrificat

images.altText: A limestone sign for the Pedernales Electric Cooperative sits in front of the large, two-story headq
images.title: Pedernales Electric Co-op
images.caption: Headquarters of the Pedernales Electric Cooperative in Johnson City

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText:
Across the street from Lyndon Johnson's Boyhood Home is the modern headquarters of the Pedernales Electric Cooperative (PEC). When Lyndon Johnson was growing up, Johnson City had no electricity, a common occurrence at that time in most rural areas around the United States. People relied on kerosene lanterns for lighting, and on windmills, horses, and the occasional gasoline motor for other jobs that were too difficult to be performed by hand.

In 1935, President Franklin Roosevelt created the Rural Electrification Administration, which encouraged rural areas to develop electrical grids by providing low-cost loans and other aid. The process was difficult, and there were significant challenges such as minimum population density requirements that needed to be overcome.

Newly elected to the U.S. House of Representatives in 1937, Lyndon Johnson immediately began lobbying the Roosevelt administration to waive the population density requirement. Meanwhile, local representatives across five Texas counties, sought support from area ranchers and residents, and in May 1938, the Pedernales Electric Cooperative was established. Later that year, Congressman Johnson was able to secure federal funds, and construction began on the infrastructure that would eventually bring electricity and the modern era to the Texas Hill Country.
audioDescription:
LBJ Legacy: Pedernales Electric Cooperative wayside. 400 words

This 3-and-a-half-foot by 2-foot graphic panel sits on the corner at the street from the Boyhood Home, which is to the far right. The panel is next to a wire fence that encloses the large, grassy side yard of the house.

Most of the panel is text. There are three black and white photos in three corners of the panel. Each white-trimmed photograph has four mounting corners. The top left photo shows a smiling man holding a jacket and hat. The caption reads "LBJ, 1939." The bottom left photo shows a seated man in suit and tie at a desk with others partially seen behind him. The caption reads "E. Babe Smith, 1947." The bottom right photo shows a crowd of dozens of men and women, some seated, some standing, all gathered in a large circle near a building. Most men wear cowboy hats. The caption reads "PEC annual meeting, 1961."

A quote is at the top of the panel: "Of all the things I have ever done, nothing has given me as much satisfaction as bringing power to the Hill Country of Texas." - Lyndon B. Johnson. The panel text reads: "In the 1930s, investor-owned utilities didn't consider it profitable to extend miles of electric line to sparsely populated regions. As a result, rural residents lived an old-fashioned, labor-intensive lifestyle. In 1935, President Franklin D. Roosevelt established the Rural Electrification Administration (R.E.A.) to encourage the formation of the rural electric cooperatives.

"After his election to U.S. Congress in 1937, Lyndon B. Johnson worked with representatives from Blanco, Burnet, Gillespie, hays and Llano counties to incorporate "Pedernales Electric Cooperative" on May 19, 1938. Despite organizational efforts, PEC could not meet the population density required for an REA loan.

"Johnson was determined to honor a campaign promise to â€˜bring the lights' to his beloved Hill Country. He obtained a private audience with President Roosevelt and successfully lobbied for a waiver. On September 27, 1938, PEC was granted a loan of about $1.3 million to extend one thousand eight-hundred miles of line to nearly three thousand families.

"The electrification of the Hill Country provided a backbone for opportunity in Central Texas, supporting the development of industries in what has become one of the fastest growing regions in America. Today, Pedernales Electric Cooperative is the largest distribution electric cooperative in the United States."

End of Description.
managedByOrg: Pedernales Electric Cooperative

title: Picnic Area (Ranch Road 1)
listingDescription: A short drive west of the state park visitor center complex is a pleasant picnic area located just off Ranch Road 1. There are four covered shelters in a scenic area with many trees and a view of the nearby Pedernales River. Each shelter has a picnic table with benches, a trash can and a grill.

Picnic Area. 68 words.

There are four spots in this picnic area; only one is on the highway side, the other three are all on the river side. The center of these three is marked as an ADA spot. title: Pool House
listingDescription:
The pool house was constructed in 1955 around the same time as the swimming pool. The small structure had space for pool equipment and maintenance and also served as a cabana with separate changing rooms for men and women.

This building is not open to the public.

images.altText: Behind a blue swimming pool, there's a small white building with yellow doors and dark windows.
images.title: Pool House
images.caption: The pool house today started as a smaller cabana in 1955.

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText:
The pool house was constructed in 1955 around the same time as the swimming pool. The small structure had space for pool equipment and maintenance and also served as a cabana with separate changing rooms for men and women.

This building is not open to the public.
audioDescription:
Pool House exterior. 155 words

Viewed from the riverside front wall, the pool house is a one story building behind the swimming pool and set off to the right. The left half of the structure is painted white and has a covered patio supported by three, white metal posts with seasonal wisteria growing on each. The patio has floor tiles and a green metal table with four chairs. There are two yellow doors, one at the left end of the building and one on the patio next to a bright orange life preserver and pool equipment hanging on the wall. There are two multi-pointed star light fixtures hanging from the patio ceiling. A glass door from the patio opens into the larger right side of the structure. This part has stonework on its back side and four large slider windows on its front. Each window is tinted black, and each window set has one screen.

End of description.

title: President Johnson's Boyhood Home (exhibit)
listingDescription: When Lyndon Johnson's father, Sam Ealy Johnson Jr., purchased the home at 200 Elm Street in 1913, he also acquired the whole block. The family's lot was 1.75 acres (.71 hectare), and it looked very different in the early 20th century. The landscape here was much more exposed with few shade trees and common low brush. The dirt yard was home to various farm animals such as a mule, a milking cow or goat, a pig, and chickens. While the house is original, other structures are reco

images.altText: Boyhood Home, smokehouse and water cistern under a canopy of live oak trees
images.title: President Johnson's Boyhood Home exhibit
images.caption: The grounds of the Lyndon B. Johnson boyhood home

relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText: When Lyndon Johnson's father, Sam Ealy Johnson Jr., purchased the home at 200 Elm Street in 1913, he also acquired the whole block. The family's lot was 1.75 acres (.71 hectare), and it looked very different in the early 20th century. The landscape here was much more exposed with few shade trees and common low brush. The dirt yard was home to various farm animals such as a mule, a milking cow or goat, a pig, and chickens. While the house is original, other structures are reconstructions in their historic locations.
audioDescription:
LBJ Boyhood Home exhibit. 359 words

This 3-and-a-half-foot by 2-foot graphic panel sits on the corner just across the street from the visitor center next to a wire fence that encloses the large, grassy backyard of the house. Close to the sign is the back of an outhouse made of weathered, grey boards. The Boyhood Home is to the far left.

The right side of the panel is filled with a black and white photograph of a young woman standing in a dirt yard, her arms around the neck of a young horse. A small barn sits in the background past barbed wire fencing. The caption reads,

"The Johnson yard looked more like a barnyard than a backyard, as the background of this photo of LBJ's cousin Ava Johnson Cox shows. Young Lyndon once broke his leg when he fell from the barn visible behind Ava."

Down the left side are two smaller photographs. The top one shows a young boy wearing a large hat, the bib of his overalls just visible. The caption reads, "Lyndon Baines Johnson, age 7."

The bottom photograph shows a dark-haired man standing in front of a microphone on the wide porch of a white house. The yard in front of him is filled with people sitting in chairs. The caption reads,

"Lyndon Johnson making a speech from the front porch of his boyhood home during his 1941 Senate campaign."

Text along the bottom of the panel reads,

"Lyndon Johnson spent most of ten years living in this home - a decade that profoundly affected the future president's view of the world. A neat landscape in front of you bears little resemblance to the backyard Lyndon Johnson knew. In Johnson's youth, this yard included almost everything needed to sustain a family: an orchard, vegetable garden, woodpile, windmill, barn, smokehouse. Hog wire fences kept in chickens and livestock. Laundry - scrubbed by hand - swayed under the intense hill country sun. Though Lyndon Johnson always thought fondly of Johnson City, he spent much of his political career trying to lessen for all Americans the hard realities he knew as a youth: no electricity, poor medical care, inadequate education, prejudice."

End of description.

title: Reconstructed Birthplace
listingDescription: In 1964, President Johnson hired architect J. Roy White of Austin, Texas to reconstruct his birthplace home on the site where the original once stood. The reconstructed birthplace is similar in size and style to the dogtrot house that Sam Ealy Johnson Sr., the president's grandfather, built in 1889, but because the Johnsons intended to use it as a guesthouse, a modern kitchen and bathroom, running water, and electricity were added. President and Mrs. Johnson then furnished th

images.altText: A white, one story house with a porch sits beyond a large pecan tree.
images.title: Reconstructed Birthplace
images.caption: Springtime at the Reconstructed Birthplace.

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText:
In 1964, President Johnson hired architect J. Roy White of Austin, Texas to reconstruct his birthplace home on the site where the original once stood. The reconstructed birthplace is similar in size and style to the dogtrot house that Sam Ealy Johnson Sr., the president's grandfather, built in 1889, but because the Johnsons intended to use it as a guesthouse, a modern kitchen and bathroom, running water, and electricity were added.

President and Mrs. Johnson then furnished the house with many objects to which they had a deep sentimental attachment, either because they had belonged to family or were gifts from special friends.

The Lyndon B. Johnson Birthplace-Cottage has the distinction of being the nation's only presidential birthplace to be reconstructed, refurnished, and interpreted by an incumbent chief executive.

What is a Dogtrot?

Stand in the open hallway of the Reconstructed Birthplace. Do you feel something? Imagine living through a hot, humid southern summer in a home before the benefit of air-conditioning. To provide shade and a cooling breeze, a covered porch area was built to separate the two main areas of the house. This is the dogtrot. By opening doors and windows, a homeowner could draw a breeze from the dogtrot throughout the house. Pets also enjoyed the cool shade, thus resulting in the name dogtrot.
audioDescription:
Birthplace. 234 words

This simple white house has vertical siding, wood shingles on the peaked roof and a stone chimney at either end. Four stone steps lead up to the wide porch with white wood railings, which extends two-thirds across the front of the house. A dogtrot opening leads through the center of the house, with doors off either side into the rooms. At the left end of the porch, another door leads into the left room. A bench sits on the porch to the right of the dogtrot. The windows on either side have dark green shutters.

The far end of the dog-trot has double doors, which stand wide open, leading to a back porch. Doors on either side of the passageway also stand open, leading to small, glass-enclosed vestibules which allow views of the furnished rooms. To the left of the left-hand door is a small push button which plays a brief history of the house narrated by Lady Bird Jonson. Also on the left-hand wall is a mirror with hooks for hats or coats and an old-fashioned telephone.

Continuing through the passageway, a wheelchair ramp leads off the right side of the back porch. To the left is a stone well with a hand pump mounted on top. A dirt path leads straight out back to a small barn structure where restrooms are located.


End of description.

title: River Creatures Exhibit
listingDescription: The area along the Pedernales River draws not only humans but wildlife as well. White-tailed deer are common in the state park at the LBJ Ranch district. A diverse variety of bird species also live here. The nature trail leads to a bird blind which can be an excellent place to quietly spot birds.Two large mammal species played an outsized role in Texas history: Americna bison and Texas longhorn.

images.altText: Framed by green foliage and grass, the view is a wide river waterfall flowing over a low dam.
images.title: River Creatures exhibit
images.caption: High water view of the LBJ Ranch low water crossing.

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

tags: lyndon B. Johnson State Park and Historic Site
bodyText:
The scenic area along the Peder­nales River draws not only humans but wildlife as well. White-tailed deer are common in the state park at the LBJ Ranch district.

A diverse variety of bird species also live here. Some are spotted along the river banks, others are seen in the forested and prairie areas of the state park. The nature trail leads to a bird blind which can be an excellent place to quietly spot birds.

Two large mammal species played an outsized role in Texas history: American bison and Texas longhorn. You can marvel at both in the state park.
audioDescription:
River Creatures wayside. 103 words.

This rectangle metal panel sits atop on stone base next to the river and low water crossing. The panel is labeled "River Creatures" in the center and is surrounded by numerous birds and fish. Each illustrated animal and label are in a gold print. Clockwise starting at the top left are a kingfisher, two mallard ducks, a great blue heron, a red sunfish, a bluegill sunfish, a channel catfish, a flathead catfish, a large mouth bass, and an American coot. Under the "River Creatures" title is a tree branch sketch with three illustrated turtles labeled Texas slider, red-eared turtle, and Texas softshell turtle.

End of description.
managedByOrg: Lyndon B. Johnson State Park and Historic Site

title: Roots of a Frontier President
listingDescription: As a child, Lyndon Johnson never tired of his grandparents' stories of 1860s life on the Texas frontier. He loved the tales of long, dusty cattle drives and bravery in the face of Comanche raids. By walking less than a mile, you can experience the setting for these stories. Along the way, you will see additional structures built by other pioneering families during the 1870s and 1880s. A stop in the Event Center will give you the opportunity to learn more about President Johns

images.altText: An old, pioneer fence stretches into the distance towards historic structures.
images.title: Roots of a Frontier President
images.caption: President Johnson felt deep pride and heritage in his grandparents' land.

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText:
As a child, Lyndon Johnson never tired of his grandparents' stories of 1860s life on the Texas frontier. He loved the tales of long, dusty cattle drives and bravery in the face of Comanche raids. By walking less than a mile, you can experience the setting for these stories. Along the way, you will see additional structures built by other pioneering families during the 1870s and 1880s. A stop in the Event Center will give you the opportunity to learn more about President Johnson's grandparents and the struggles they faced to carve out a life in the Texas Hill Country. It will also acquaint you with the transformation that took place as open range gave way to fenced pastures and farms.

President Johnson did not forget the hardships that his ancestors endured. He drew strength from his frontier roots as he faced his own challenges as President of the United States.
audioDescription:
Roots of a Frontier President wayside. 423 words

This 3-and-a-half-foot by 2-foot graphic panel sits on the right side of the path leading from the pullout along Highway 290 to the historic Johnson Settlement area. Split-rail fences enclose pastures on either side of the path and the historic structures are visible ahead of you.

The panel shows a simple map of the settlement area with north behind you. Your current location is at the bottom right with the path leading up to the looping path which connects the historic structures. Another, larger loop provides walking paths to the left, with a trail leading left across Town Creek to the National Park Service Visitor Center. Pictures of the structures surround the smaller loop. Clockwise from upper left there is the Event Center, where restrooms are located, the Sam E. Johnson Cabin, the Bruckner Barn, the James P. Johnson Barn, and the N.T. Stubbs Cooler House. A note on the sign indicates that all areas are wheelchair accessible.

At the bottom center of the panel are ovals with portraits of Sam Ealy Johnson Sr. at left, a dark-haired man with goatee and mustache, wearing a jacket with a wide lapel. On the right is Eliza Bunton Johnson, a woman with dark hair pulled back with a hat on top, long ribbons hanging down in back. Her dress is tightly gathered at the waist with a wide belt.

At the upper right is a quote which reads,

"As a branding iron sears flesh, the memories of the Texas Hill Country etched themselves on Lyndon Johnson's cortex. - Journalist Hugh Sidey."

At left, text reads,

"As a child, President Lyndon B. Johnson never tired of his grandparents' stories of 1860s life on the Texas frontier. He loved the tales of long, dusty cattle drives and bravery in the face of Comanche Indian raids. By walking less than a mile, you can experience the setting for these stories. Along the way, you will see additional structures built by other pioneering families during the 1870s and 1880s. A stop in the Event Center will give you the opportunity to learn more about President Johnson's grandparents and the struggles they faced to carve out a life in the Texas Hill Country. It will also acquaint you with the transformation that took place as open range gave way to fenced pastures and farms.

"President Johnson did not forget the hardships that his ancestors endured. He drew strength from his frontier roots as he faced his own challenges as President of the United States."


End of description.

Self-sufficiency was a must; the nearest store was in Blanco, a day's ride away. The Johnson cabin is typical of the "dogtrot" cabins that were once common in Texas. The shaded breezeway-t

images.altText: A log cabin with two rooms separated by a breezeway sits on green grass under a blue sky.
images.title: Sam Ealy Johnson Sr. Cabin
images.caption: The weathered log cabin of President Johnson's grandparents

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText:
For five years (1867–1872) this cabin was the home of Samuel Ealy Johnson and his wife Eliza. While Sam ran the family's cattle business, Eliza attended by hand to virtually every detail of running the ranch. She hauled water, spun wool, made clothes, cooked meals, and tended the animals. Self-sufficiency was a must; the nearest store was in Blanco, a day's ride away.

The Johnson cabin is typical of the "dogtrot" cabins that were once common in Texas. The shaded breezeway—through which a dog could easily trot—provided storage space and much-needed relief during the hill country's blistering summers. The west wing, nearest you, was built first, in 1856; Sam Johnson added the east wing about 1868.
audioDescription:
Samuel E. Johnson, Sr. Cabin exterior. 279 words

The weathered, gray cabin consists of two rooms separated by a wide breezeway. The walls are made of rough-hewn wooden beams with concrete filling the thick gaps. The wood-shingled roof stretches over both rooms and extends both front and back to cover wide wooden porches. Two stone steps in the middle lead up to the porch in front.

Each of the rooms has a stone chimney at the outer end, side windows with plain wooden shutters, and a single door opening onto both the front and rear porches. The rooms have simple furnishings which may be viewed through the glass covering the open doorways. The righthand room includes a bed covered with a quilt, a cradle, a wash stand, and a spinning wheel. The room on the left has a table with small stools, shelves on the walls with pans and mixing bowls, and a screen-fronted cabinet holding dishes, cups and glasses.

Benches sit on the front porch on either side of the breezeway. On a right-side wall about 18 feet from the front steps past the doorway is a button, which may be pressed to hear a brief history of the cabin narrated by Luci Johnson, younger daughter of President and Mrs. Johnson.

In front of the cabin on the right is a large stone well covered by a thick stone slab with a round hole in the middle, now covered with a sheet of acrylic. A ramp alongside the right side of the cabin provides wheelchair access to the back porch.

The back porch looks out over grassy fields. To the right behind the cabin is a smaller log building and farther back is an outhouse.

End of description.

title: Sam E. Johnson Sr. House
listingDescription: Sam and Eliza Johnson were among the first and most successful Hill Country cattle drovers, settling near what is now Johnson City in the late 1860s. After amassing a fortune, they lost it, and eventually resettled here along the Pedernales, where, Eliza Johnson remembered, "the tempo of life was slower." Sam lived here until his death in 1915. Eliza lived here until 1917. Both are buried in the Johnson family cemetery.

images.altText: A red house with white-trim whites is behind a white picket fence, all under large shade trees.
images.title: Sam Ealy Johnson Sr. House
images.caption: The Sam Ealy Johnson Sr. House

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText:
The scene was a common one: young Lyndon Johnson, only a few years old, toddling down the road to visit his grandparents in this house. Here he found a ready supply of apples, candy, and affection. The future president felt a powerful attraction to his paternal grandparents, Sam Johnson Sr. and Eliza Bunton Johnson; he would always identify himself with the frontier struggles they had endured.

Sam and Eliza Johnson were among the first and most successful Hill Country cattle drovers, settling near what is now Johnson City in the late 1860s. After amassing a fortune, they lost it, and eventually resettled here along the Pedernales, where, Eliza Johnson remembered, "the tempo of life was slower." Sam lived here until his death in 1915. Eliza lived here until 1917. Both are buried in the Johnson family cemetery.
audioDescription:
Sam E. Johnson, Sr. House. 143 words

This is a small house, a simple rectangle with a sloping roof and chimneys made of stone blocks on either end. The vertical siding is painted red with white trim around the windows and the doors. The roof is covered with corrugated tin. The right two-thirds of the front of the house is a screened-in porch.

The house sits back from the road with grassy fields surrounding it and spreading live oak trees scattered about. A white picket fence encloses the immediate yard around the house. A dirt lane on the right side of the house leads to a pasture out back. To the right of the lane are a corral, a barn and some smaller out buildings.

Just to the left of the house, along the edge of the road are two wayside graphic panels.


End of description.

title: Sam Sr. and Eliza Johnson House (Wayside)
listingDescription: Upon leaving president Johnson's grandparents' home, enjoy the drive through the live oak grove to the next two sites, the Cedar Guest House and Oriole Bailey House. Along the way keep an eye out for wildlife which love to take advantage of the shade provided by these beautiful trees. Commonly seen are whitetail deer and blackbuck antelope. If you spot a bird with a long, forked tail doing acrobatic maneuvers to catch insects, you have seen a scissor-tailed flycatcher.

images.altText: Tall, leafy trees create lots of patchy shade for a few cows resting along a winding road.
images.title: Sam Sr and Eliza Johnson House (wayside)
images.caption: The scenic LBJ Ranch driving tour route

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText: Upon leaving President Johnson's grandparents' home, enjoy the drive through the live oak grove to the next two sites, the Cedar Guest House and Oriole Bailey House. Along the way keep an eye out for wildlife which love to take advantage of the shade provided by these beautiful trees. Commonly seen are whitetail deer and blackbuck antelope. If you spot a bird with a long, forked tail doing acrobatic maneuvers to catch insects, you have seen a scissor-tailed flycatcher.
audioDescription:
Sam and Eliza Johnson Home. 411 words

This 3-and-a-half-foot by 2-foot graphic panel is the right panel of the two along the road in front of the Sam Sr. house. The small, red house behind its white picket fence is slightly to the right, grassy fields and outbuildings at either side.

The right side of the panel is filled with an old, black and white photograph of a large family, posing on and around an old automobile. At the right side is a gray-haired woman, sitting in a wheelchair. A dark-haired man stands behind her, using a hat to shade the woman's head. A gray-haired man with beard and mustache sits in the driver's seat. Other men and women sit and stand on either side and behind him. A number of children cluster around, sitting on the fenders and standing on the running boards. One boy leans against the front of the car, squinting in the bright sun. The caption reads,

"Sam Ealy Johnson Sr. with his wife Eliza and family members gather around a Model T Ford parked in the driveway of this home. Lyndon Johnson may be the boy standing in front of the car."

Text down the left side of the panel reads,

"The scene was a common one: young Lyndon Johnson, only a few years old, toddling down the road to visit his grandparents in this house. Here he found a ready supply of apples, candy, and affection. The future president felt a powerful attraction to his paternal grandparents, Sam Johnson Sr. and Eliza Bunton Johnson; he would always identify himself with the frontier struggles they had endured. Sam and Eliza Johnson were among the first and most successful Hill Country cattle drovers, settling near what is now Johnson City in the late 1860s. After amassing a fortune, they lost it, and eventually resettled here along the Pedernales, where, Eliza Johnson remembered, â€˜the tempo of life was slower.' Sam lived here until his death in 1915. Eliza lived here until 1917. Both are buried in the Johnson family cemetery."

Below the text are early portraits of Sam and Eliza Johnson. The one on the left shows a dark-haired man with goatee and mustache, wearing a jacket with a wide lapel. The one on the right shows a woman with dark hair pulled back with a hat on top, long ribbons hanging down in back. Her dress is tightly gathered at the waist with a wide belt.


End of description.

title: Sauer Beckman Living History Farm
listingDescription: Johann and Christine Sauer settled this land in 1869. Their family prospered and, by 1885 several stone buildings were built near the original rock and log cabins. Eventually, the Sauers had 10 children. One of those, Augusta Sauer Lindig, served as midwife at the birth of President Johnson. The Beckmann family acquired the property in 1900. In 1966, Edna Beckmann Hightower sold the site to the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department.

images.credit: Photo courtesy of LBJ State Park
images.altText: A windmill towers over a white frame farmhouse dating circa 1918.
images.title: Sauer Beckmann Living History Farm
images.caption: The Sauer-Beckmann Living History Farm depicts rural Hill Country life as it was around 1918.

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

tags: lyndon B. Johnson State Park and Historic Site
bodyText:
When visitors can smell lunch being cooked on a wood-burning stove, they are close to the Sauer-Beckmann Living Farm! Here, costumed interpreters carry out the day-to-day activities of a turn-of-the-century Texas-German farm family. Some chores are seasonal, such as canning and butchering. Farm animals, however, must be cared for on a daily basis, including activities like feeding, milking, gathering eggs and slopping the hogs. Also, the house is cleaned, meals are cooked, butter is churned and cheese is made. Visitors may see the "family" scrubbing the floors with homemade lye soap, or plowing the garden with a team of horses.

The setting for the present-day living history activities is an authentic Hill Country farm. Johann and Christine Sauer, along with their four children, settled this land in 1869. Their family prospered and grew and, by 1885, several stone buildings were built near the original rock and log cabins. Eventually, the Sauers had 10 children. One of those, Augusta Sauer Lindig, served as midwife at the birth of President Johnson.

The Beckmann family acquired the property in 1900. A good cotton crop in 1915 allowed Emil and Emma Beckmann to build a new barn, to add a frame room onto the old rock structure, and to construct porches connecting to a lovely Victorian house covered with fashionable pressed tin. In 1966, Edna Beckmann Hightower sold the site to the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department. Archeological surveying and restoration work was undertaken and the farm opened to the public in 1975. Since then, time has stood still and the farm remains forever a small piece of Texas as it was at the beginning of the 20th century. Park visitors can experience the farm at their leisure and groups can make arrangements for tours.
audioDescription:
Sauer-Beckmann Living History Farm. 324 words.

This three foot wide graphic panel stands approximately three feet high to the right of the gated entrance to the Sauer Beckmann Living History Farm. On a green background, it is titled "Sauer-Beckmann Living History Farm. Step back in time... to experience German Texas farm life from 1915 to 1918."

There are four small pictures, including an older man waving in overalls and a cowboy hat, a large wooden barn, a side view of the living history farm structures and a boy examining an indoor exhibit. At the bottom of the panel is a short timeline with three pictures of historic structures; from left to right, the photos are labeled Danz Cabins 1861, Behrens Cabin 1872, and Sauer-Beckmann Living History Farm 1915.

Most of the panel consists of text which reads:

"Here, costumed interpreters carry out the day-to-day activities of a turn-of-the-century German-Texas farm family. You might spot them plowing the garden with a team of horse, or watch them tend the farm animals. Daily chores include milking, gathering eggs and slopping the hogs. Household duties include cooking, scrubbing the floors and homemade lye soap, canning, churning butter and making cheese.

"Johann and Christine Sauer and their four children settled this land in 1869. By 1885, they had built several stone buildings near the original rock and log cabins. Eventually, the Sauers had ten children. One of those, Augusta Sauer Lindig, served as midwife at President Johnson's birth.

"The Beckmann family acquired the property in 1900. A good cotton crop in 1915 allowed Emil and Emma Beckmann to make several improvements to the homestead. They built porches connecting to ta lovely Victorian house covered with fashionable tin. They also added a frame room onto the old rock structure and built a new barn.

"In 1966, Edna Beckmann Hightower sold the site to the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department. Archeological surveys and restoration work were undertaken and the farm opened to the public in 1975."

End of Description
managedByOrg: Lyndon B. Johnson State Park and Historic Site

Four years and four children later, they settled this land in 1869. Their family prospered and grew and, by 1885, several stone buildings were built near the original rock and log cabins. Eventually, the Sauers had 10 children. One of them, Augusta Sauer Lindig, served as midwife at the birth of Lyndon B. Johnson in 1908.With most of their children out on the

images.credit: Photo courtesy of LBJ State Park
images.altText: A woman does laundry outside in the yard of the farmhouse using a scrub board and metal washtubs.
images.title: Sauer Cabins
images.caption: Before the arrival of indoor plumbing and electricity to the Hill Country, chores were done by hand.

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

tags: lyndon B. Johnson State Park and Historic Site
bodyText:
Johann Frederick Sauer and his wife Christine, both immigrants from Germany, married in nearby Fredericksburg in 1865. Four years and four children later, they settled this land in 1869. Their family prospered and grew and, by 1885, several stone buildings were built near the original rock and log cabins. Eventually, the Sauers had 10 children. One of them, Augusta Sauer Lindig, served as midwife at the birth of Lyndon B. Johnson in 1908.

With most of their children out on their own by 1900, the Sauers sold the farm to Herman Beckmann and moved closer to their sons in Doss. The Beckmanns used the Sauer cabin as a living space until their own home was completed. Later, they converted the Sauer cabins into work and storage space. Today, state park staff and volunteers use the historic home as the Beckmanns did in 1915.
audioDescription:
Sauer Cabins. 132 words.

Two separate but adjoined structures create the Sauer Cabins. Both have broken gable roofs with the rake of the roof on the sides and the ridge of the roof running long above the entry. The left structure is slightly taller but narrower than the right part. Both front porches have three posts to hold up the shingled roof eaves. The left side of the left porch is enclosed by wood planks. There is a stone chimney attached on the left side. The left structure is stone construction covered with white stucco. It has an open entry door from the porch and one double hung window. The right structure is a log and rock construction; in between each wooden log there is a row of chinking stones. There is an open entry door.

End of Description
managedByOrg: Lyndon B. Johnson State Park and Historic Site

title: Settlement Event Center
listingDescription:
The Settlement Event Center contains exhibits about pioneer life, cattle droving, and ranching during the time of Lyndon Johnson's grandparents. Across the walkway there are restrooms, a water fountain, and a water bottle filling station.

This building can be rented for special events and functions under a Special Use Permit.
Event Center Rental Information

images.altText: A large, stone building with a two-tiered roof and a wide, dark breezeway has a park sign our front.
images.title: Settlement Event Center
images.caption: Escape the elements and enjoy the exhibits at the Event Center.

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText: The Settlement Event Center contains exhibits about pioneer life, cattle droving, and ranching during the time of Lyndon Johnson's grandparents. Across the walkway there are restrooms, a water fountain, and a water bottle filling station.
audioDescription:
Settlement Event Center. 403 words

The event center is a long, rectangular stone building. The roof extends to cover a veranda around the outside where wooden rocking chairs sit. A breezeway extends through the center of the building to a trail into the historical settlement area on the other side. On the left side of the breezeway are restrooms and water fountains. On the right side is the entrance into an exhibit area.

The veranda and breezeway are paved with brick tiles. Although single-story, the walls extending above the veranda roof are lined with horizontal windows to light the interior of the building.

In front of the center to the right of the path is a grassy area with about a dozen picnic tables under the tall trees.

Behind the center, the dirt path curves back to the left again crossing the small creek. A sign just to the right of the bridge reads,

"For your safety: You are entering a historical area restored to nineteenth century conditions. Some of the natural and historic features could be hazardous to you. Please watch your step. Observe farm animals from a distance. Supervise your children closely."

Also behind the center is a metal sign which reads,

"After the Civil War, Lyndon B. Johnson's grandfather, Sam Ealy Johnson, Sr., brought his bride Eliza to this place to live in a â€˜dog-trot' cabin. Sam and his brother, Tom, bought cattle on speculation to drive in great herds over the Chisholm Trail to the railhead in Kansas.

The legendary cattle drives were long and hard and sometimes deadly; Tom drowned at a river-crossing in 1877. But equally long and hard were the days for families left behind on this isolated frontier. With the men gone on the long drive, Eliza faced constant difficulties and dangers, including Indians who still resisted the white man's invasion. On top of the occasional danger, however, was the plain backbreaking work of it all; to thrive on this frontier demanded seemingly endless daily toil and sacrifice.

In 1871 the cattle market collapsed - too many cattle - and Sam and Eliza Johnson moved to Hays County, near Austin. Later they returned to this area to settle near Stonewall on land that would one day become part of the LBJ Ranch. There they lived to see the birth of their grandson, a future president of the United States."

End of description.

title: Settlement Warnings
listingDescription: The Johnson Settlement is where Lyndon Johnson's grandparents first settled in the Texas Hill Country. His grandfather, Sam Ealy Johnson Sr. was a cattle drover, rounding up cattle here in the Hill Country and herding them north along the Chisholm Trail to the railheads in Abilene, Kansas. From there cattle were sold to growing eastern cities with a large demand for beef.The settlement is restored to its appearance in about 1870 and contains many of the original buildings and

images.altText: A modern sign stands in front of an old, wooden, pioneer fence.
images.title: Settlement Warnings
images.caption: Near the Hwy 290 parking area entrance to the Johnson Settlement

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText:
The Johnson Settlement is where Lyndon Johnson's grandparents first settled in the Texas Hill Country. His grandfather, Sam Ealy Johnson Sr. was a cattle drover, rounding up cattle here in the Hill Country and herding them north along the Chisholm Trail to the railheads in Abilene, Kansas. From there cattle were sold to growing eastern cities with a large demand for beef.

The settlement is restored to its appearance in about 1870 and contains many of the original buildings and a restored prairie landscape. The National Park Foundation purchased the land in the early 1970s with money donated by Lyndon Johnson.

Restrictions & Warnings

The trail is open from dawn to dusk. Bikes are allowed on the shared-use trail. Dogs on leash are permitted. Do not approach livestock or wildlife. Smoking is allowed only in approved outside areas near the Event Center.
audioDescription:
Johnson Settlement Restrictions and Warnings. 212 words

This vertical graphic panel is 3 and a half feet wide and stands 6 feet tall. It is mounted to the right at a point where the cement sidewalk changes to a boardwalk with a low wooden curb on each side. The background of the sign is filled with a photograph of a flat, green pasture with a couple of grazing horses at the right. In the distance is a green tree line with scattered, small white and grey buildings. In the upper right corner is a picture of a longhorn steer, its body brown and its white face turned to look directly at us.

Text at the left reads,

"Bicycles are allowed only on pathways. Hikers and cyclists should be mindful of shared use.

Smoking is allowed only at the Event Center.

Dogs must be leashed at all times. Protection of others and park livestock and wildlife requires a leash not longer than six feet.

Livestock are unpredictable and can be dangerous. Please do not feed or approach the animals.

Use of the settlement area (unless otherwise authorized by special use permit) is dawn to dusk.

Group use of the Event Center requires a special use permit. Applications are available at the park's headquarters."

End of description.

title: Show Barn
listingDescription: The Show Barn’s primary purpose was the upkeep of ranch’s herd of Hereford show cattle. Ranch hands could maintain both registered and commercial stock here.

images.altText: Under a roof with metal rafters, numerous metal pens line either side of a central dirt walkway.
images.title: Show Barn
images.caption: Inside the historic Show Barn

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText:
Prior to the Show Barn's construction, the ranch's agricultural operations took place near the Texas White House. The cattle pens were attached to the old Martin Barn just west of the home. When Lyndon B. Johnson became president, the role of the ranch expanded. Daily presence and activity of guests, reporters, and US Secret Service increased.

Construction of the Show Barn began in 1964 and was completed in 1966. It was built on a hill and at an angle to take advantage of breezes for keeping the cattle cool and dispersing unpleasant odors. Constructed of metal trusses and H-shaped perimeter supports, the gabled building has open sides where the cattle pens are located. The office, wash rack, and storage areas have concrete masonry unit walls and concrete floors, whereas the open alleys and pens have an earth floor.

The Show Barn's primary purpose was the upkeep of ranch's herd of Hereford show cattle. Ranch hands could maintain both registered and commercial stock here.
audioDescription:
Show Barn. 126 words

This is a long, rectangular building open on the sides with a dirt floor. At the left end on one side is an enclosed extension that runs along half the length. The other sides are lined with open stalls enclosed by metal fencing. Sometimes cattle may be found in the stalls. A wide center aisle leads down the center of the barn. At the far left end is an open carport where ranch vehicles may be parked. The ranch road curves around that end, where there is a small parking area to the left of the road and three wayside signs. The right end of the barn opens into a fenced area with more fenced corrals across the road at that end.


End of description.

title: Show Barn (wayside)
listingDescription: Although ranching produced just a fraction of the Johnsons' income, it constituted a major portion of the President's public identity. The Johnsons maintained two herds of cattle on the LBJ Ranch-one of them a commercial herd sold for beef, the other a herd of about 500 registered Herefords, sold for breeding purposes. The registered Herefords on the ranch today are descendants of the animals owned by President Johnson. The show barn was the center of the ranching operation,

images.altText: While a few folks watching from the fence, the president pulls a rope with a calf at the end.
images.title: Show Barn (wayside)
images.caption: The president ropes a calf at his ranch.

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText: Although ranching produced just a fraction of the Johnsons' income, it constituted a major portion of the President's public identity. The Johnsons maintained two herds of cattle on the LBJ Ranch—one of them a commercial herd sold for beef, the other a herd of about 500 registered Herefords, sold for breeding purposes. The registered Herefords on the ranch today are descendants of the animals owned by President Johnson. The show barn was the center of the ranching operation, where equipment was stored and the ranch's five or six employees reported to work. Here ranch hands prepared cattle for showing, both to prospective buyers and at shows throughout Texas. Herdsmen trained and fitted the show cattle. Each animal represented a considerable investment; at that time a prize-winning bull was worth between $500 and $1500.
audioDescription:
The Show Barn wayside. 432 words

This 3-and-a-half-foot by 2-foot graphic panel sits at the right side of the road as it curves around the end of the barn. There are two signs here. This is the one on the right. Beyond the sign, the backside of the barn extends out away from us next to a grassy area shaded by trees.

The right side of the panel is filled with a black and white photograph of President Johnson on horseback facing us as he heads for a cow in the foreground. He wears a shirt and tie with a casual jacket. His mouth is open as he focuses on the cow, his hat in his right hand, his left pulling the reins to the left. The caption reads,

"Before he purchased the ranch in 1951, most Americans saw Lyndon Johnson as a small-town Southern senator. But with the ranch came the image of a Texas rancher and businessman - an impression more acceptable to the national electorate."

At the bottom left of the panel is a large, blue chest with the lid open, standing near the metal fence of a stall in the barn. A painted sign on the inside of the lid reads, "The LBJ Ranch, Stonewall, Texas." A length of rope dangles over the side of the box. The caption reads,

"Grooming tools, harnesses, and other supplies were kept in a show box, like this replica, for easy transport to local fairs and cattle shows."

At the top center of the panel is an image of a shield-shaped plaque. The engraved lettering reads, "Champion Female Hereford, Kendall County Fair, 1963." The caption reads,

"LBJ's Herefords frequently won awards, such as this champion prize presented at the 1963 Kendall County Fair."

Text at the upper left reads,

"Although ranching produced just a fraction of the Johnsons' income, it constituted a major portion of the President's public identity. The Johnsons maintained two herds of cattle on the LBJ Ranch - one of them a commercial herd sold for beef, the other a herd of about 500 registered Herefords, sold for breeding purposes. The registered Herefords on the ranch today are descendants of the animals owned by President Johnson. The show barn was the center of the ranching operation, where equipment was stored and the ranch's five or six employees reported to work. Here ranch hands prepared cattle for showing, both to prospective buyers and at shows throughout Texas. Herdsmen trained and fitted the show cattle. Each animal represented a considerable investment; at that time a prize-winning bull was worth between $500 and $1500."


End of description.

title: Smoke House-Sauer Beckmann Farm
listingDescription: Built by the Sauers sometime before 1900, this limestone smokehouse served the farm well. While today it does double duty as a smokehouse and a cool place to store vegetables, the Sauers and the Beckmanns used the downstairs for smoking meat and the upstairs for storage. To smoke meats like sausage, hams, and bacon, a small bucket is filled with bark and wood chips and placed on the floor. A small fire is set in the bucket, and a lid (one with holes in it) is placed on the bu

images.altText: A tall, limestone building with a shingled roof has a screen door entry.
images.title: Smokehouse - Sauer Beckmann Farm
images.caption: The smokehouse also serves as dry storage.

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

tags: lyndon B. Johnson State Park and Historic Site
bodyText:
Built by the Sauers sometime before 1900, this limestone smokehouse served the farm well. While today it does double duty as a smokehouse and a cool place to store vegetables, the Sauers and the Beckmanns used the downstairs for smoking meat and the upstairs for storage.

To smoke meats like sausage, hams, and bacon, a small bucket is filled with bark and wood chips and placed on the floor. A small fire is set in the bucket, and a lid (one with holes in it) is placed on the bucket. The fire is left to smolder. The meat is typically smoked overnight. Then the meat is left to hang for several weeks as it is cured by the salt mixed with it and the dryness of the smokehouse. Once it is fully cured, the meat is taken and stored in lard or preserved through the canning process.
audioDescription:
Smoke house. 30 words.

This tall structure is made of large blocks of limestone. The wooden shingle roof sits on limestone gable end walls. With one small step up, a screen door allows entry.

End of Description
managedByOrg: Lyndon B. Johnson State Park and Historic Site

title: Swimming Pool
listingDescription: The Johnsons had a kidney-shaped pool, long enough for laps and deep enough for diving. Like the ranch and like their home, it was a place for family time and for the business of politics.

images.altText: While he reads papers, the president holds a dog in a swimming pool next to his young grandson.
images.title: Swimming Pool
images.caption: The master multi-tasker takes a swim.

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText:
In July 1955, Senator Johnson suffered a severe heart attack at a friend's estate in Virginia. After nearly a month at Bethesda Naval Hospital and a second month at home in Washington, DC, he was permitted by doctors to return to his Texas ranch for further recovery. Even before the heart attack, the Johnsons were planning to build a swimming pool southeast of their home.

During his convalescence, the pool, a cabana, and area landscaping were planned and constructed under his watchful eye. For a multi-tasking man with an incredibly active mind, taking on this project was an effective way to pass the time while regaining his health. The senator would set up a yard chair outside to observe the excavation of the gaping hole and the pouring of concrete.

In the end, the Johnsons had a kidney-shaped pool, long enough for laps and deep enough for diving. Like the ranch and like their home, it was a place for family time and for the business of politics.
audioDescription:
Swimming Pool, 123 words.

From the front stone wall, situated in between the Texas White House and the pool house, there is a large, kidney-shaped pool. The wider section on the left is shallow compared to the right side which is narrow and deep. A long diving board is at the far right end of the pool, hanging over the deep side. Closest to the front stone wall is the shallowest section with only one step in the water. Across the shallow end, a steel, curved handrail leads to three steps in the water. On the right, two curved, metal handrails lead to four ladders steps in the deep end. The whole pool has a trim of red bricks and a paved sidewalk following its entire circumference.

End of Description

title: Tank house-Sauer Beckmann Farm
listingDescription: This tank house was built by the Sauers before they sold the farm in 1900. While it is used to store laundry supplies today, the structure's primary purpose is to hold the large water tank on top. This cypress tank holds several hundred gallons of water. The tank is filled by the windmill next to it pumping water from a 50-foot deep well. The tank provides extra water storage as well as gravity fed pressure to the water faucet next to it.

images.altText: A large wooden cistern sits on a square limestone building.
images.title: Tank House - Sauer Beckmann Farm
images.caption: Water source during the dry times

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

tags: lyndon B. Johnson State Park and Historic Site
bodyText: This tank house was built by the Sauers before they sold the farm in 1900. While it is used to store laundry supplies today, the structure's primary purpose is to hold the large water tank on top. This cypress tank holds several hundred gallons of water. The tank is filled by the windmill next to it pumping water from a 50-foot deep well. The tank provides extra water storage as well as gravity fed pressure to the water faucet next to it.
audioDescription:
Tank House. 81 Words.

With the Sauer Cabins behind you, this large, square structure is made from blocks of limestone. It has a flat roof with white trim. Atop the roof is a barrel made of wooden planks held together by metal loops. There is an open white door to enter the small structure, and there is one square window on the left side. The windmill is behind the tank house from here and is connected to the rooftop barrel by a long metal pipe.

End of Description
managedByOrg: Lyndon B. Johnson State Park and Historic Site

title: Tetrahedron
listingDescription: The tetrahedron is a wind direction device used to guide aircraft into the LBJ Ranch. It is mounted on a swivel, so that it can turn, and it will point into the wind. Knowing the wind direction is important for pilots. Takeoffs and landings are always done into the wind.

images.altText: Under white clouds, a gray triangular pyramid sits with dark letters L-B-J on its side.
images.title: Tetrahedron
images.caption: The tetrahedron acts like a windsock, helping pilots see wind direction.

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText: The tetrahedron is a wind direction device used to guide aircraft into the LBJ Ranch. It is mounted on a swivel, so that it can turn, and it will point into the wind. Knowing the wind direction is important for pilots. Takeoffs and landings are always done into the wind.
audioDescription:
Tetrahedron. 126 words

About fifty yards off the paved driving tour route is the tetrahedron. From the direction of travel, it is located on the left across a field of grass. It is shaped like a triangle with a short edge on its left side and long top and bottom edges reaching a common point on the right side. At this right side point, a weighted bucket hangs. The triangle can pivot in the wind on a central, concrete base. The perimeter of the triangle has a dashed line and large rivets on both sides. In black letters is the text "L-B-J" on one side. The tetrahedron structure is surrounded on all four sides by a dark, picket fence about four feet high.

End of description.

title: Texas White House Virtual Tour

images.altText: A large, white, two-story home is shaded by massive oak trees.
images.title: Texas White House Exterior View
images.caption: Step inside the historic Texas White House on a virtual tour.

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText:
As a boy, Lyndon Johnson knew the home of his Uncle Clarence and Aunt Frank Martin as "the big house on the river." In 1951 he took ownership of the house from his widowed aunt, and the expanding home and associated LBJ Ranch became a center of political activity for nearly 20 years. During the presidential years, the nation and world came to know the big house on the river as the Texas White House.

Today the majority of rooms have been restored to their appearance during the presidential years (1963-1968) while the master bedroom suites retain their appearance at the time of President and Mrs. Johnson's deaths (1973 and 2007, respectively).

Currently the Texas White House is not open for tours while the National Park Service completes an assessment of the structure—parts of which are over a century old—and prepares for an extensive rehabilitation of the home. However, this virtual tour will allow you to explore the first floor of the Texas White House and learn more about many of the objects on display.

Go To Virtual Tour

title: Texas: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park
listingDescription: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park is located in Stonewall, Texas about 50 miles west of Austin. The Park protects the birthplace, home, ranch, and final resting place of Lyndon B. Johnson, 36th President of the United States who is most well-know for the civil rights legislation passed during his administration.

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText:
Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park is located in central Texas about 50 miles west of Austin in the Texas Hill Country. The park protects the birthplace, home, ranch, and final resting place of Lyndon B. Johnson, 36th President of the United States.

In November 1963 President Kennedy was assasinated in Dallas, Texas. This occurred as civil rights legislation began to take shape in Congress. President Lyndon Johnson addressed Congress five days after Kennedy's assassination, urging them to pass the bill. Johnson was famous for his tactics in getting legislation passed even as a member of Congress himself (he served in both the House and the Senate), before serving in the White House, and he used these skills to pressure Congress into passing what would eventualy become the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

The Voting Rights Acts was a result of two things: 1. The elimination of the voting rights provision in the original Civil Rights Act of 1964 and 2. The Selma to Montgomery March in March 1965, which was a peaceful 54-mile march in an effort to register black voters in the South. The marchers were met with extreme violencefrom local authorites and white terrorists groups. Six days after the march, LBJ pledged his support for a Voting Rights Act.

Following Dr. King's assassination in Memphis, Tennessee on April 4, 1968, President Johnson used the political climate at the time to push for more civil rights legislation. In a ltter to Congree, Johnson invoked Dr. King's assassination, imploring Congress to act in the name of a man "who devoted his life to nonviolent achievement of rights that most Americans take for granted..." On APril 10, 1968, the day after Dr. King's funeral, the House voted to pass the Civil RIghts Act of 1968 (commonly referred to as the Fair Housing Act of 1968).

The Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park was chosen for inclusion in the African American Civil Rights Network in October 2019.

The African American Civil Rights Network (AACRN) recognizes the civil rights movement in the United States and the sacrifices made by those who fought against discrimination and segregation. Created by the African American Civil Rights Act of 2017, and coordinated by the National Park Service, the Network tells the stories of the people, places, and events of the modern U.S. civil rights movement from 1939 -1968 through a collection of public and private elements.

title: The Environmental First Lady
listingDescription: Lady Bird Johnson's environmental ethic spanned her entire lifetime of 94 years. A child of East Texas, she spent many of her days outdoors. The sense of place that came from being close to the land never left her. She would eventually carry that with her to the White House. The Beautification Act of 1965, known as "Lady Bird's Bill," is a well-known result of her tireless work.

images.altText: Holding her shoes, Lady Bird Johnson smiles as she walks along the beach in the surf.
images.title: The Environmental First Lady
images.caption: The First Lady walks in the surf at Padre Island National Seashore.

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText:
Lady Bird Johnson's environmental ethic spanned her entire lifetime of 94 years. A child of East Texas, she spent many of her days outdoors. The sense of place that came from being close to the land never left her. She would eventually carry that with her to the White House.

The Beautification Act of 1965, known as "Lady Bird's Bill," is a well-known result of her tireless work. Often associated only with wildflowers, Lady Bird Johnson emphasized that "beautification" meant much more. It meant clean water, clean air, clean roadsides, and preservation of landmarks, parks, and wilderness areas.

Her commitment to the natural world resulted in a national awareness not seen prior to her time as first lady, and it served as a catalyst for the modern environmental movement. Lady Bird Johnson demonstrated that through the activism of one person great change can happen.
audioDescription:
The Environmental First Lady. 322 words

This 3-and-a-half-foot by 2-foot graphic panel sits at the left side of the road that loops through the ranch property. On either side are large, flat grassy fields. A low tree line is visible in the distance.

The background of the panel is filled with a color photograph of President and Mrs. Johnson sitting in a field covered with wildflowers. The flowers have flat yellow petals and red-orange centers. The president wears a casual jacket and a hat. Mrs. Johnson wears a sleeveless white blouse. At bottom right a quote reads,

"The environment...is not only a mirror of ourselves, but a focusing lens on what we can become. - Lady Bird Johnson."

At bottom left is a small, black and white photograph of Mrs. Johnson with a small dark-skinned boy. Together they hold a shovel and scoop up a mound of dirt. A crowd of young people with a couple of adults stands around them. The caption reads,

"Planting trees in Washington, DC, 1968."

Text at the top of the panel reads,

Lady Bird Johnson's environmental ethic spanned her entire lifetime of 94 years. A child of East Texas, she spent many of her days outdoors. The sense of place that came from being close to the land never left her. She would eventually carry that with her to the White House.

"The Beautification Act of 1965, known as â€˜Lady Bird's Bill,' is a well known result of her tireless work. Often associated only with wildflowers, Lady Bird Johnson emphasized that â€˜beautification' meant much more. It meant clean water, clean air, clean roadsides, and preservation of landmarks, parks and wilderness areas. Her commitment to the natural world resulted in a national awareness not seen prior to her time as first lady, and it served as a catalyst for the modern environmental movement. Lady Bird Johnson demonstrated that through the activism of one person great change can happen."


End of description.

listingDescription: Growing up in the scenic Texas Hill Country, Lyndon Johnson developed a deep appreciation and respect for the land. As part of his dream for a "Great Society," he felt a responsibility to protect the natural heritage of the United States. During his administration President Johnson signed nearly 300 conservation measures into law, forming the basis of the modern environmental movement. Included among the legislation were bills to ensure clean air and protect water quality. La

images.altText: President and Mrs. Johnson touch hands while sitting in a large field of yellow wildflowers.
images.title: The Environmental President
images.caption: The Johnsons fought for the urgent necessity of the environment.

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText:
Growing up in the scenic Texas Hill Country, Lyndon Johnson developed a deep appreciation and respect for the land. As part of his dream for a "Great Society," he felt a responsibility to protect the natural heritage of the United States. During his administration President Johnson signed nearly 300 conservation measures into law, forming the basis of the modern environmental movement. Included among the legislation were bills to ensure clean air and protect water quality. Laws governing waste disposal and pesticide use were put into effect. Protection for endangered animals was initiated.

Wilderness areas and a national trails system were created. Nearly 50 new national park areas were added and existing ones expanded, ensuring that many more Americans would have the opportunity to enjoy the natural, historic, and cultural beauty of the nation.
audioDescription:
The Environmental President. 285 words

This 3-and-a-half-foot by 2-foot graphic panel sits at the left side of the road that loops through the ranch property. On either side are large, flat grassy fields. A tree line is visible in the distance.

The background of the panel is filled with a color photograph of President Johnson standing amidst tall plants lining the bank of a river. He wears a light brown, casual-style jacket and a hat. He peers into the water. The caption reads,

"Standing along the Pedernales River, July 1968."

At upper left is a small, black and white photograph of the president sitting at a small table as he signs a paper, a row of pens in a stand beside him. A group of men in dark suits, huddle around him, watching. The caption reads,

"Signing the Clean Air Act of 1967."

Text on the left side of the panel reads,

"Growing up in the scenic Texas Hill Country, Lyndon Johnson developed a deep appreciation and respect for the land. As part of his dream for a â€˜Great Society' he felt a responsibility to protect the natural heritage of the United States. During his administration President Johnson signed nearly 300 conservation measures into law, forming the basis of the modern environmental movement. Included among the legislation were bills to ensure clean air and protect water quality. Laws governing waste disposal and pesticide use were put into effect. Protection for endangered animals was initiated. Wilderness areas and a national trails system were created. Nearly 50 new national park areas were added and existing ones expanded, ensuring that many more Americans would have the opportunity to enjoy the natural, historic, and cultural beauty of the nation."


End of description.

title: The Jet Age Arrives!
listingDescription: In October 1961 the United States Air Force replaced twin-engine, propeller-driven aircraft with the four-engine Lockheed JetStar for executive transport. Lyndon Johnson was the first vice president to have an aircraft assigned to him. His choice was the Lockheed JetStar C-140B (VC). As president he continued to use the JetStar for travel to and from his ranch. He jokingly referred to the plane as "Air Force One-Half," although it did bear the call sign Air Force One.

images.altText: Looking down on asphalt, there sits a small white and blue plane.

images.caption: Aerial view of the jetstar at the LBJ Ranch.

images.altText: Past a nearby wooden fence under leafless trees, there are historic structures in the far distance.
images.title: The Johnson Cabin (exhibit)
images.caption: View of the Johnson Cabin from the Settlement Trail

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText:
For five years (1867–1872) this cabin was the home of Samuel Ealy Johnson and his wife Eliza. While Sam ran the family's cattle business, Eliza attended by hand to virtually every detail of running the ranch. She hauled water, spun wool, made clothes, cooked meals, and tended the animals. Self-sufficiency was a must; the nearest store was in Blanco, a day's ride away.

The Johnson cabin is typical of the "dogtrot" cabins that were once common in Texas. The west wing was built first, in 1856; Sam Johnson added the east wing about 1868. The shaded breezeway—through which a dog could easily trot—provided storage space and much-needed relief during the hill country's blistering summers.
audioDescription:
The Johnson Cabin exhibit. 323 words

This 3-and-a-half-foot by 2-foot graphic panel sits on the right side of the path near the cabin itself. Behind the sign is a small fenced enclosure made of vertical posts with sharpened ends. Just to the left is the cabin with a stone well in front.

The panel is filled with a black and white photograph of the cabin taken from the left front corner. A group of people stands in front, three men wearing suit jackets and big hats and two women in dresses. The man in the middle holds a small girl in his arms. The caption reads,

"President Johnson reveled in telling the story of his frontier grandparents - Indian raids, domestic toil, hardships of the trail. In this 1940s photo, he tours the cabin with (left to right) Uncle Tom Johnson, Rebekah Johnson, daughter Lynda Johnson in LBJ's arms, Uncle Berry Roebuck and Lady Bird Johnson."

At lower right is a small portrait of Eliza Bunton Johnson, LBJ's paternal grandmother. She has dark hair pulled back with a hat on top, long ribbons hanging down in back, and a string of black beads wound twice around her neck.

Text along the bottom of the panel reads,

"For five years (1867 - 1872) this cabin was the home of Samuel Ealy Johnson and his wife Eliza. While Sam ran the family's cattle business, Eliza attended by hand to virtually every detail of running the ranch. She hauled water, spun wool, made clothes, cooked meals, and tended the animals. Self-sufficiency was a must; the nearest store was in Blanco, a day's ride away. The Johnson cabin is typical of the â€˜dogtrot' cabins that were once common in Texas. The west wing, nearest you, was built first, in 1856; Sam Johnson added the east wing about 1868. The shaded breezeway - through which a dog could easily trot - provided storage space and much-needed relief during the hill country's blistering summers."

End of description.

title: The Junction School
listingDescription: The Junction School opened on November 21, 1910 and served the area for 37 years. In the spring of 1947 the school became part of the Stonewall Consolidated School District. With this move, the Junction School closed and its students attended the nearby Stonewall School. In 1972 the National Park Foundation purchased the land to become part of the Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park.

images.altText: A gray building with a shingled roof has tall windows on its side and a stepped entrance at its end.
images.title: The Junction School
images.caption: The education of the future president began here.

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText:
The one-room school was very important to the rural people living in Gillespie County. Here, near their homes, the children learned the "3Rs"—reading, writing, and arithmetic—enabling many of them to go on to high school and college. The schools were located close enough to children's homes to allow to them to walk to school. There were 31 one-room schools located in Gillespie County.

The Junction School was a typical one-room school. A wood stove sat in a sand box in the center of the school and was the only source of heat. Two kerosene lamps suspended from the ceiling at opposite ends of the room provided light. The teacher's desk and a chair were in front of the classroom. A small brass bell on the teacher's desk summoned the students. Students sat at double desks which had wooden tops with holes for the glass inkwells. The desks were arranged in rows facing the teacher's desk; the boys in one row and the girls in another.

The Junction School opened on November 21, 1910 and served the area for 37 years. In the spring of 1947 the school became part of the Stonewall Consolidated School District. With this move, the Junction School closed and its students attended the nearby Stonewall School. In 1972 the National Park Foundation purchased the land to become part of the Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park.
audioDescription: Junction School. 197 words. This school is a simple, block building. It is covered in tin pressed to resemble stone blocks and painted gray. The back of the building faces the small parking area. A low wooden porch at back may be reached by three steps in the rear or a short ramp to the left of the steps. From the porch a door leads into a small exhibit area where the interior has been furnished to show how it might have looked around 1912. A push button mounted to the exhibit wall may be pressed for an audio recording about the school and its connection to Lyndon Johnson. The front of the building has a double door made of wood and a flag pole to the left. A long set of concrete steps leads down to the road, where a large, brown park service sign reads, "Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park. LBJ Ranch." There are four, double-hung windows on each side of the building and the peaked roof is covered with wood shingles. A single metal stove pipe sits on the ridgeline. When standing at the rear, facing the building, a round, covered well sits to the right. To the left, along the side of the building is a wooden table, which has a graphic panel on its top. Another sign is located at the side of the road in front of the building. End of description.

title: The LBJ Legacy: Pedernales Electric Co-op
listingDescription: Just as Johnson City helped shape Lyndon Johnson, Lyndon Johnson helped shape the modern face of Johnson City. Throughout the town are buildings that reflect Johnson's quest to ease the hardships he knew here in his youth. The former LBJ Hospital-now the park visitor center-is one of them.The white stone building east of the boyhood home is the headquarters of the Pedernales Electric Cooperative or PEC, one of Lyndon Johnson's most important contributions to the people of the

images.altText: A tall Lyndon Johnson examines a new light fixture with an older woman in her kitchen.
images.title: LBJ Legacy: Pedernales Electric Co-op
images.caption: Lyndon Johnson examines an electric light fixture, 1941.

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText:
Just as Johnson City helped shape Lyndon Johnson, Lyndon Johnson helped shape the modern face of Johnson City. Throughout the town are buildings that reflect Johnson's quest to ease the hardships he knew here in his youth. The former LBJ Hospital—now the park visitor center—is one of them.

The white stone building east of the boyhood home is the headquarters of the Pedernales Electric Cooperative or PEC, one of Lyndon Johnson's most important contributions to the people of the Texas Hill Country. Throughout the summer of 1938, freshman congressman Lyndon Johnson stumped hard for rural electrification. His arguments convinced wary farmers and ranchers that the cost would be worth the elimination of hand-pumped water, hand-washed laundry, and red-hot cook stoves. In 1939, electricity flowed to thousands of hill country residents for the first time.
audioDescription:
The LBJ Legacy wayside. 419 words

If you stand with your back to the Visitor Center, this graphic panel is mounted at the right corner of the paved area beyond the covered patio. Past the sign a grassy lawn extends down to the street with the back of Johnson's boyhood home visible one block away. The sign is about 3 and a half feet wide and 2 feet high supported by a metal frame on two posts.

The background of the graphic panel has a black and white photograph of four men on horseback in front of a sign that reads, "Johnson City, Home of World's Largest Rural Electrification System." Lyndon B. Johnson stands between a couple of the horses, dressed in a suit and wearing a wide hat.

At the left side of the panel a quote reads,

"The Pedernales Electric Cooperative. â€˜Of all the things I have ever done, nothing has given me as much satisfaction as bringing power to the Hill Country of Texas.' Lyndon Johnson, January 1, 1959."

Text across the top of the panel reads,

"Just as Johnson City helped shape Lyndon Johnson, Lyndon Johnson helped shape the modern face of Johnson City. Throughout the town are buildings that reflect Johnson's quest to ease the hardships he knew here in his youth. The former LBJ Hospital—now the park visitor center behind you—is one of them.

"The white stone building to the right of the boyhood home is the headquarters of the Pedernales Electric Cooperative or PEC, one of Lyndon Johnson's most important contributions to the people of the Texas hill country. Throughout the summer of 1938, freshman congressman Lyndon Johnson stumped hard for rural electrification. His arguments convinced wary farmers and ranchers that the cost would be worth the elimination of hand-pumped water, hand-washed laundry, and red-hot cook stoves. In 1939, electricity flowed to thousands of hill country residents for the first time."

In the lower right corner is a photograph of a group of men in suits posing in three lines on the steps in front of a building. In the front of the grouping is a young, dark-haired man wearing white shirt and tie, but no jacket. The caption reads,

"Johnson not only brought electricity to the hill country, he also brought the $40,000 PEC Headquarters building to Johnson City. Here the young congressman stands in front of the PEC in 1940."

End of description.
