Visitors to the ranch l

images.altText: An aerial view shows green pastures, several structures and roads, a river, and distant hills.
images.title: The LBJ Ranch: A Living Legend
images.caption: Aerial view of the ranch and Pedernales River in 1967

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText:
The LBJ Ranch was suddenly thrust upon the world stage when Lyndon Johnson assumed the presidency following the assassination of John F. Kennedy. Relatively unknown to the nation before November 1963, the Johnson family's Hill Country retreat became the second most significant location in the country after the White House.

President Johnson introduced the world to Texas as he used the property for cabinet meetings, conferences, and diplomatic functions. Visitors to the ranch left with a new understanding of the president. The LBJ Ranch, like the man, became larger than life—a place of myth and legend.

In December 1972, the Johnsons deeded their home to the National Park Service. The former president encouraged the NPS to use the ranch as a site for teaching about US history and agriculture. Today, visitors continue to come from around the world to have their own LBJ Ranch experience.
audioDescription:
The LBJ Ranch: A Living Legend. 316 words

This 3-and-a-half-foot by 2-foot graphic panel is on the right side of the ranch road as it heads south towards the Texas White House Complex. Out beyond the sign is a large grassy pasture on the other side of a post-and-wire fence. A few trees stand along the fence line.

The background of the panel is filled with an aerial photograph from 1967 of the Texas White House Complex. At upper left is an asphalt pad where a small jet plane is parked. In the foreground is the Texas White House, partially obscured by trees, with a white fence lining the road in front. At right, the swimming pool is visible and a pole flying a large American flag. Other buildings lie behind and to the left. A quote at top right reads,

"It was important that the Ranch continue to thrive as a working ranch, not become a sterile relic of the past. Lady Bird Johnson, 1998."

Text along the bottom of the panel reads,

"The LBJ Ranch was suddenly thrust upon the world stage when Lyndon Johnson assumed the presidency following the assassination of John F. Kennedy. Relatively unknown to the nation before November 1963, the Johnson family's Hill Country retreat became the second most significant location in the country after the White House. President Lyndon Johnson introduced the world to Texas as he used the property for cabinet meetings, conferences, and diplomatic functions. Visitors to the ranch left with a new understanding of the president. The LBJ Ranch, like the man, became larger than life - a place of myth and legend.

"In December 1972, the Johnsons deeded their home to the National Park Service. The former president encouraged the NPS to use the ranch as a site for teaching about US history and agriculture. Today, visitors continue to come from around the world to have their own LBJ Ranch experience."


End of description.

multimedia.title: The LBJ Ranch: A Living Legend

In 1964 President and Mrs. Johnson had the building in front of you constructed as a guest house for visitors to the LBJ Ranch. It stands on the site of, and closely resembles, the origin

images.altText: A well dressed family of ten stand in front of a worn, one story ranch house on a barren landscape.
images.title: The Reconstructed Birthplace (wayside)
images.caption: President Johnson's grandparents stand at the original home with family in the late 1800s.

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText:
Near this site at dawn on August 27, 1908, the future 36th President of the United States was born. He was the first child of Sam Ealy Johnson Jr.—a state legislator—and Rebekah Baines Johnson, an educator and journalist. Lyndon Baines Johnson lived here for the first five years of his life.

In 1964 President and Mrs. Johnson had the building in front of you constructed as a guest house for visitors to the LBJ Ranch. It stands on the site of, and closely resembles, the original home that was removed in the 1930s. Though never intended as a literal reconstruction, 'the birthplace' was furnished with Johnson family mementos spanning many generations.
audioDescription:
The Reconstructed Birthplace exhibit. 382 words

This 3-and-a-half-foot by 2-foot graphic panel sits about halfway along the path that leads from the parking area to the birthplace house. It is surrounded by a mowed grassy area dotted with trees. The small white house can be seen to the right, on the other side of a wood rail fence.

The lower part of the panel is filled with an old photograph of 10 people standing in a line in front of a small house. An older man stands in the middle wearing a dark suit and a gray beard. There are five women of various ages on either side of him, along with two younger men, a girl and a young boy. The house behind them has a covered porch along the right two-thirds of the front with a dog-trot opening leading back through the middle of the house. There is a stone chimney at each end of the house. The caption reads,

"The original birth home was built in 1889 by the president's grandfather, Sam Ealy Johnson, Sr., shown here in front of the house with his wife, Eliza, and family. Lyndon Johnson's parents moved here after their marriage in 1907. They farmed the surrounding land between Sam's trips to the legislature in Austin."

At the upper right are two small photographs. One shows a baby. The caption reads,

"Lyndon Baines Johnson, six months old."

The other shows four men in front of the house, President Johnson and another man in front. The caption reads,

"President Johnson on the grounds with his friend, Reverend Billy Graham."

Text at the upper left reads,

"Near this site at dawn on August 27, 1908, the future 36th President of the United States was born. He was the first child of Sam Ealy Johnson Jr. —a state legislator—and Rebekah Baines Johnson, an educator and journalist. Lyndon Baines Johnson lived here for the first five years of his life. In 1964 President and Mrs. Johnson had the building in front of you constructed as a guest house for visitors to the LBJ Ranch. It stands on the site of, and closely resembles, the original home (removed in the 1930s). Though never intended as a literal reconstruction, 'the birthplace' was furnished with Johnson family mementos spanning many generations."


End of description.

title: The Texas White House
listingDescription: The home of Lyndon and Lady Bird Johnson at the LBJ Ranch was a place of family and of politics...as well as a place for rejuvenation. During his five-year administration, President Johnson spent a quarter of his time here-74 visits totaling 490 days. To the world, it became known as "The Texas White," but for the Johnson family, it was simply known as "Our Heart's Home."

images.altText: Shade from trees covers a green lawn and a sidewalk leads up to a large, white, two-story home.
images.title: The Texas White House
images.caption: The home of President and Mrs. Johnson

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText:
The home of Lyndon and Lady Bird Johnson at the LBJ Ranch was a place of family and of politics...as well as a place for rejuvenation. During his five-year administration, President Johnson spent a quarter of his time here—74 visits totaling 490 days. To the world, it became known as "The Texas White," but for the Johnson family, it was simply known as "Our Heart's Home."

While Lyndon Johnson was growing up, it was the home of his Uncle Clarence and Aunt Frank Martin. Some of his earliest memories as a young boy were of the "big house on the river." The house he loved for decades became his in 1951 after he purchased it and approximately 240 acres from his widowed aunt.

As his career grew, so did the house and its functions. The Johnsons added an office in 1958 when he was senate majority leader. In 1962, the dining room and kitchen were both extended to create additional space for entertaining when he was vice president. Additional bedrooms and bathrooms were created and remodeled to house invited guests including world leaders such as the President of Mexico, West German Chancellor, and Israeli Prime Minister. In 1967, late in his presidency, the couple added two master suites for the comfort of their upcoming retirement.

In the end, the Texas White House expanded to include 28 rooms (8 bedrooms, 9 bathrooms) spanning over 8,400 square feet.
audioDescription:
The Texas White House. 492 words

This 3-and-a-half-foot by 2-foot graphic panel sits at side of the house, near the white fence that encloses the front yard. The yard with its shady trees lies beyond the sign with the house itself slightly to the left. Around the fence corner to the right is the front fence overlooking the whole Texas White House. The structure description follows the panel description.

The panel is filled with a black and white photograph of a group of men around a table on a lawn, stone wall visible in the back ground. The men sit in lawn chairs, some with notepads in their laps, other leaning on the paper-strewn table. Most wear dark suits or military uniforms. President Johnson sits at left, in shirtsleeves, as he looks on papers on the table. The caption reads,

"President Johnson meets with his military advisors and Joint Chiefs of Staff in the front yard of the Texas White House, December 22, 1964."

Text at the bottom of the panel reads,

"Although he lived in Washington for much of his adult life, President Johnson always considered this house his home. During the White House years it served as a busy office, a working ranch, and a quiet refuge from the pressures of being president in tumultuous times. The shade of the big live oak in front of you often served as a makeshift meeting room for the Johnson cabinet.

"President Johnson's capacity to influence or control events did not diminish during his stays at the Texas White House. Outbuildings held sophisticated electronics. Airplanes and helicopters buzzed along the ranch's runway. Inside the house, Johnson met with staff, read papers, watched television, and worked the phones constantly. He also hosted a steady procession of cabinet officers, legislators, celebrities, and heads of state."

Description Continues...

Moving to the right around the fence corner is a full view of the house. From here, the largest live oak tree is set on the left side of the yard. Beyond the tree, there is a one story room with a field stone wall and chimney on its far left and a long porch at its front. Connected to the right of this porch begins a two-story structure made of large blocks of limestone. Its small porch has four white columns and an entry door and window. The second story roof is gabled.

To its right is an identical gabled roof above first floor bay windows on a wooden structure. The two gabled roofs are connected by a first floor porch and second floor porch balcony with cross railing. There are green hedges in front of the porches. Attached to the bay windowed room is a single-story addition with a window and roof skylight and three larger windows to the right. At the far right of the building is a short, side porch with stone steps. The swimming pool is on the far right side of the yard beyond another live oak tree.

End of description.

title: The Working Corrals
listingDescription: President Johnson always kept a close eye on his ranch operations. The image of him handling steers or working a bull is appealing, but most of the physical labor on the ranch was done by a handful of ranch hands-many of them long-time employees, such as Dale Malechek, the ranch foreman.This, said Lyndon Johnson, was "where the cattle go out and the money comes in." In the working pens, ranch hands tended to the herds-branding, castrating, doctoring, and, most importantly, lo

images.altText: Hereford cow and calf look through metal fencing of pen.
images.title: The Working Corrals
images.caption: Hereford cow and calf in the Show Barn

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText:
President Johnson always kept a close eye on his ranch operations. The image of him handling steers or working a bull is appealing, but most of the physical labor on the ranch was done by a handful of ranch hands—many of them long-time employees, such as Dale Malechek, the ranch foreman.

This, said Lyndon Johnson, was "where the cattle go out and the money comes in." In the working pens, ranch hands tended to the herds-branding, castrating, doctoring, and, most importantly, loading cattle out for shipment after a sale.

The ramp in front of you is a "loading chute" for loading cattle into trucks. The majority of cattle shipped off the ranch were from the Johnson's beef herd—some of which he would simply purchase, clean up, and resell at a profit. Though LBJ was proudest of his registered Herefords (sold for breeding), much of his ranching revenue came from the sale of unregistered beef cattle.
audioDescription:
The Working Corrals wayside. 333 words

This 3-and-a-half-foot by 2-foot graphic panel is the left panel of the two that sit along the road near the Show Barn. Beyond the sign, the backside of the barn extends out away from us next to a grassy area shaded by trees, with white-fenced corrals out behind. Beyond that to the left is a small white ranch house and farm buildings.

The right side of the panel is filled with a black and white photograph of President Johnson dressed in shirt, slacks and a dark sweater, with a hat on his head. He faces us grinning, as his left hand pulls on a rope attached to the halter of a Hereford calf behind him.

At the bottom left of the panel is a picture of a Hereford bull hitched to fencing at the side of a barn with other cattle similarly tied up behind him. A man in a plaid shirt bends over, grooming the side of the bull. The caption below reads,

"President Johnson always kept a close eye on his ranch operations. The image of him handling steers or working a bull is appealing, but most of the physical labor on the ranch was done by a handful of ranch hands - many of them long-time employees, such as Dale Malechek, ranch foreman."

Text at the upper left reads,

"This, said Lyndon Johnson, was â€˜where the cattle go out and the money comes in.' In the working pens, ranch hands tended to the herds - branding, castrating, doctoring, and, most importantly, loading cattle out for shipment after a sale. The ramp in front of you is a â€˜loading chute' for loading cattle into trucks. The majority of cattle shipped off the ranch were from the Johnson's beef herd - some of which he would simply purchase, clean up, and resell at a profit. Though LBJ was proudest of his registered Herefords (sold for breeding), much of his ranching revenue came from the sale of unregistered beef cattle."


End of description.

title: Trinity Lutheran Church

images.altText: A gray-blue church with tall steeple stands against the backdrop of a bright blue sky.
images.title: Trinity Lutheran Church
images.caption: The Johnsons often attended services at Trinity Lutheran while at home on the LBJ Ranch.

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText:
The congregation of Trinity Lutheran Church traces its history to 1902, when it was first organized in the nearby Albert, Texas schoolhouse. The members donated funds to purchase three acres of land overlooking the Pedernales River, and a small sanctuary was built here in 1904, just across from where Lyndon Johnson would be born in 1908. The elegant structure you see today was constructed in 1928. A fine example of the Gothic Revival style of architecture, the church features lovely arched window and door openings, a Gothic steeple, and its original pressed-metal siding. Worship services were conducted in the German language until 1950.

Although President Johnson was a member of the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) and Lady Bird Johnson was Episcopalian, they would frequently attend services at Trinity Lutheran while at home on the LBJ Ranch.

The church grounds also became the site for one of the first Head Start Schools in the nation. Operation Head Start was a strategic program in President Johnson's Great Society educational program. Launched in the summer of 1965, Head Start provides pre-school children with health, nutrition, education, and other social services. Since its founding, more than 36 million children have participated in Head Start programs, preparing them for the classroom at schools around the country. After his retirement, Lyndon Johnson would visit the Stonewall Head Start, arriving with candy for the children who knew him, not as "Mr. President," but as "Mr. Jelly Bean."
audioDescription: This church is built in the Gothic Revival style of architecture; it features arched window and door openings and a steeple that rises 100 feet to the top of a cross. The exterior of the church is pressed metal siding meant to resemble stones. The building is painted a light blue with white trim.
managedByOrg: Trinity Lutheran Church of Stonewall, Texas

title: US Secret Service Command Post
listingDescription: Initially, this cottage was used for employees of the LBJ Ranch. Although the US Secret Service had a presence on the ranch beginning with Johnson’s vice presidency in 1961, the agency did not have permanent quarters. Early in the Kennedy-Johnson administration, a trailer was placed on the property northeast of the main house. Secret Service used the trailer until around 1966, at which point the agency began to use the cottage. It served as a security post and office.

images.altText: A five-pointed star on a blue circle background represents the Secret Service emblem.
images.title: U.S. Secret Service Command Post
images.caption: A historic USSS emblem marks the entrance to the Command Post

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText:
This historic cottage was originally constructed on the south side of the Pedernales River where today the Lyndon B. Johnson State Park exists. It was used by the Beckmann family in the 1940s for about a decade. After it was abandoned and unoccupied, the family sold the house to Lyndon Johnson, and it was moved to its current location in the late 1950s.

Initially, the cottage was used for employees of the LBJ Ranch. Although the US Secret Service had a presence on the ranch beginning with Johnson's vice presidency in 1961, the agency did not have permanent quarters. Initially, agents assigned to the ranch had posts in the Klein Shop or even in their automobiles.

At some point early in the Kennedy-Johnson administration, a trailer was placed on the property northeast of the main house. After Johnson became president in November 1963, Secret Service continued to use the trailer until around 1966, at which point the agency began to use the old Beckmann cottage. It served as a security post as well as office space for Johnson's protection detail.
audioDescription:
Secret Service Command Post. 140 words.

A one-story white building stands in a grass yard behind a square, white fenced perimeter. The structure has beveled wood siding painted white and windows of differing sizes and mostly double-hung on each side. A single door on the right side is the only entry point. This front of the house faces east. On the door, a five-pointed star with rounded tips on a circular, blue background has text at its center in a circular fashion. The text is: "United States Secret Service, The Department of the Treasury." In the center of the circle is a blue and red shield symbol resembling a columned building. The main view of the structure for visitors is from the south behind the perimeter fence. This main view has a large picture window on the right and a smaller, double-hung window on the left.

End of Description.

title: Volunteer RV Sites
listingDescription: Near the north end of the airstrip, this area was previously used for military barracks during the Johnson presidency. Today, the scenic spot is used as a RV campground for the Volunteers-In-Park. For their service working with interpretation, ranching, maintenance or curatorial, our talented volunteers are given a space to use during their time at the park.

images.altText: Two RVs sit under the shade of trees within an enclosed Volunteers-In-Parks campsite area.

images.caption: Park volunteers have the opportunity to live at the LBJ Ranch

Today, the scenic spot is used as a RV campground for the Volunteers-In-Park. For their service working with interpretation, ranching, maintenance or curatorial, our talented volunteers are given a space to use during their time at the park.

Volunteer-In-Park RV Sites. 49 words

A few gravel spaces long enough for recreational and personal vehicles are located off a private road. The area is off the driving tour route, behind a perimeter fence and enjoys the shade of several large live oak trees. There is also a small utility building on the grounds.

title: Watering the Landscape: Valley Irrigation
listingDescription: Water is a valuable resource for ranchers in the Texas Hill Country. The Pedernales River and the many local creeks are the main sources of water for irrigation. As droughts are common here, supplemental irrigation was necessary for President Johnson to maintain his fields of oats, winter wheat, and grass.The Valley Irrigation Systems rolled across the landscape providing precious water to a thirsty land. Johnson understood that water was priceless. He enacted several pieces

images.altText: A metal irrigation apparatus stands on wheels in a green field.
images.title: Watering the Landscape: Valley Irrigatio
images.caption: An irrigation system helps the working ranch

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText:
Water is a valuable resource for ranchers in the Texas Hill Country. The Pedernales River and the many local creeks are the main sources of water for irrigation. As droughts are common here, supplemental irrigation was necessary for President Johnson to maintain his fields of oats, winter wheat, and grass.

The Valley Irrigation Systems rolled across the landscape providing precious water to a thirsty land. Johnson understood that water was priceless. He enacted several pieces of legislation to ensure wise use of water resources. He once said he wanted to be remembered as the "conservation president."
audioDescription:
Watering the Landscape. 324 words

This 3-and-a-half-foot by 2-foot graphic panel sits at the left side of the narrow road that loops through the back of the ranch property. On either side are large, flat grassy fields stretching out into the distance. In the field behind you is an irrigation system. A long pipe with sprinkler heads is mounted on wheeled stanchions so it can be moved through the field.

The background of the panel is filled with a black and white photograph of President Johnson examining his fields in 1954. Facing away from us, a man sits on a tractor pulling a large rake-like device in a stubble-covered field. President Johnson stands behind the tractor wearing a wide hat and in his shirt sleeves. One foot rests on a tine of the rake while he looks at a bunch of grass in his hand.

In the bottom left corner are two smaller images. One is a photograph of an irrigation system like the one in the field behind you. The long pipe rests on widely spaced structures, shaped like tall triangles with two wheels at the bottom. Wires from the peak of the triangles support the pipe. The other picture shows a yellow metal sign attached to one of the irrigation triangles. It reads, "Valley self-propelled, Valmont Industries, Inc."

Text at top left of the panel reads,

"Water is a valuable resource for ranchers in the Texas Hill Country. The Pedernales River and the many local creeks are the main sources of water for irrigation. As droughts are common here, supplemental irrigation was necessary for President Johnson to maintain his fields of oats, winter wheat and grass. The Valley Irrigation Systems rolled across the landscape providing precious water to a thirsty land. Johnson understood that water was priceless. He enacted several pieces of legislation to ensure wise use of water resources. He once said he wanted to be remembered as the â€˜conservation president.'"


End of description.

title: Welcome to the Hangar
listingDescription: The Airplane Hangar has served many functions over the years. Finished around 1959, it was initially constructed to protect then Senator Johnson's private plane from the elements. The spacious hangar faced the taxiway and had a wide carport in the back. In between the hangar and carport, two small quarters were built to house staff. Early on, the hangar was used for hay storage at one point, but during Johnson's presidency, it was a gathering place for community and political

images.altText: A large cloud sits above the gable roof of a large green building with glass windows.
images.title: Welcome to the Hangar
images.caption: History awaits you in the Airplane Hangar

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText:
The Airplane Hangar has served many functions over the years. Finished around 1959, it was initially constructed to protect then Senator Johnson's private plane from the elements. The spacious hangar faced the taxiway and had a wide carport in the back. In between the hangar and carport, two small quarters were built to house staff. Early on, the hangar was used for hay storage at one point, but during Johnson's presidency, it was a gathering place for community and political events as well as for official press conferences. The hangar was even used as a movie theater for the Johnson family and their friends. Today, it has been repurposed as the LBJ Ranch District visitor center, complete with exhibits, park film, and bookstore.

The Many Functions of the Hangar

Hay was not the only thing that has been stored in the hangar. Zoom into this December 29, 1963 photo. Underneath the wings of the aircraft is a stack of lumber. In this photo, President Johnson takes Secretary of Defense Robert McNamara ( front passenger seat ) and others for a spin in the golf cart. Jack Valenti ( pictured in the dark jacket directly behind Johnson ) follows on foot.

Protecting aircraft from the elements was the primary purpose for the hangar. In this 1965 photo, President Johnson has a conversation underneath the open hangar door. Today the hangar door has been opened permanently to allow a wall of glass windows to be added, thus giving visitors a panoramic view of the ranch from inside. Step inside the hangar and underneath the open door; look up and through a glass ceiling to see the hangar door.

The hangar, with it's size and open space, made an ideal location for press conferences during President Johnson's time in office. Joining the president for this September 1967 press conference are Lynda Bird Johnson and her fiancé Captain Charles Robb ( far right ).

Parties and dinners were often held in the hangar as well. On November 6, 1968, a dinner for military support personnel and their families was held. President Johnson spoke to the approximately 300 in attendance with his grandson, Patrick Lyndon Nugent, by his side. Notice the wall paneling, ceiling tiles, and lights which can still be seen in the hangar today.
audioDescription:
Welcome to the Hangar wayside. 247 words

This 3-and-a-half-foot by 2-foot graphic panel sits on the paved area in front of the hangar. The wide hangar building, with its gently sloping roof is now covered in front with a glass wall. The entrance doors are at the left end. The JetStar, protected under an open-sided, silver metal structure, is behind you, to the right. The parking area, historically the taxiway to the airstrip, is to the left. Various other buildings of the complex are farther behind the hangar. Behind you is another wayside sign. The ground surface surrounding the hangar, auxiliary buildings, and parking is one level of continuous asphalt.

The background of the panel is filled with a black and white photograph of the hangar from the front, a small, two-engine plane parked just inside. In the foreground, President Johnson, wearing a shirt and tie under a casual jacket, is driving a golf cart towards us. Riding in the cart are two men in suits and two in military uniform. Two other men are visible behind the cart. The caption reads,

"President Johnson takes Secretary of Defense Robert McNamara (front passenger seat) and others for a spin in the golf cart. Jack Valenti (pictured in the dark jacket directly behind Johnson) follows on foot. December 29, 1963."

Text at the top reads,

"Built in 1959 to store aircraft and ranch supplies, the hangar now serves as a visitor center containing exhibits and displays. Step inside to learn more about President Johnson and to purchase your tickets for a tour of the Texas White House."

End of description.

title: Windmill and Water Tank
listingDescription: The windmill and water tank are located near a big live oak tree behind the house. The windmill was a Dempster model, and the water tank was originally situated in a tank house. images.altText: A large metal tank sits high on a wooden frame underneath branches of a large live oak tree.
images.title: Windmill and Water Tank
images.caption: Gravity-fed water would have been a luxury in Lyndon Johnson's youth.

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText: The windmill and water tank are located near a big live oak tree behind the house. The windmill was a Dempster model, and the water tank was originally situated in a tank house. For many years, the Johnson family did not have indoor plumbing. However, by the early 1920s, they had gravity-fed water to their house. Using wind power, the windmill would draw the water from the well into the storage tank. From there, water flowed with the pressure of gravity through pipes in the ground to the house.
audioDescription:
Windmill and Water Tank. 184 words

From the back side of the Boyhood Home and exiting a wire perimeter fence, these two structures are in front of you in the grass beyond the gravel trail you're on.

The windmill sits atop a tall, slender, pyramidal metal tower. From the triangular base, it is about twenty feet to the top of the fan. The fan is circular, close to five feet in diameter with narrow, metal blades and a large, flat vertical metal tail extending behind it. Nearby tree branches have grown in close to the fan. A long pipe extends from the gear mechanism at the top straight down into a small, square concrete base that covers the well below the tower.

Six feet or so behind the windmill is a round, galvanized water tank sitting atop an approximately ten-foot tall wooden stand. The tank is about 5 feet in diameter. From the top of the tank, one pipe extends to connect to the windmill. Another pipe on the left stretches from the bottom of the tank down into the ground.

End of description.

title: Windmill, Water Tank, Cooler House
listingDescription: The Cyclone windmill pumped cold well water into the adjoining storage tank. The well water then flowed by gravity through a pipe to the wooden water trough inside the cooler house where perishable food and dairy products were kept.

images.altText: Behind a tree, there is a limestone building, a wooden cistern on stilts and a wooden windmill.
images.title: Windmill, Water Tank, Cooler House
images.caption: Working together: the windmill, the water tank and the cooler house

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText:
Windmill


The Cyclone windmill situated above the well pumped the cold well water into the adjoining storage tank. Its many blades allowed for the windmill to hold up to the pressure of strong winds and still generate enough torque to pump water from the well during periods of low winds. The well water then flowed by gravity through a pipe to the wooden water trough inside the cooler house. Wind was an important resource that the settlers harnessed. Cooperation with nature was an integral part of life.

Water Tank


The water tank is an essential part of the pumping process. It stores water above the height of where it will be used, and then is gravity-fed into water troughs and buildings. No electric or mechanical energy source is required for this part of the process.

Cooler House


The original cooler house was built in the 1880s by N.T. Stubbs, a cousin by marriage to President Lyndon B. Johnson. The cooler house provided cold storage for perishable food and dairy products. It was constructed out of native limestone with walls 18 inches thick. Inside, shelves were built along the thick stone walls for storage of crocks filled with wild dewberries, hog plums, and garden vegetables such as onions, peas, beans, and tomatoes. Cans of milk and churns filled with cream for making butter were kept cool in the wooden water trough. Eggs, preserved in salt, and cabbage, stored in barrels for making sauerkraut, were kept on the cool, moist sand floor, while potatoes and other root vegetables were stored in a large box, layered with sand to keep them dry.
audioDescription:
Windmill, Water Tank and Cooler House. 219 words

These three structures are in a line, facing away from you as you stand on the path. At the right is a small, stone building, about 15 feet by 20 feet, with a wood shingled roof. There are no windows, only a narrow wooden door on the far side.

In the middle, about 8 feet to the left of the building is a round, wooden water tank sitting on top of an eight-foot tall wooden stand. The structure is about 5 feet by 5 feet. From the top of the tank one pipe extends to the windmill on the left. Another pipe on the right stretches from the top of the tank down into the ground.

The windmill at the left end of the group sits on a tall, slender pyramidal wooden tower. The rectangular base is about 6 feet square and it sits about 5 feet to the left of the water tank. It is about 20 feet to the top of the fan. The fan is circular, close to six feet in diameter, with narrow wooden blades and has a large, flat vertical wooden tail extending behind it. A long pipe extends from the gear mechanism at top down into a stone-covered well at the base of the tower.


End of description.

title: Withers and Spauldings General Store
listingDescription: The historic Withers & Spauldings General Store now serves as an exhibit area and information center for Johnson City. Visitors can learn about Johnson City shopping and dining options as well as additional attractions in the surrounding Hill Country community.

images.altText: Close-up of store front with "Withers & Spauldings" sign in white letters on a maroon background.
images.title: Withers & Spauldings
images.caption: The old general store now houses the local chamber of commerce.

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

bodyText:
In the early 20th century, general stores were an important fixture in small, rural towns such as Johnson City. Not only did they provide "store-bought goods," but they served as social centers and community message centers. Shoppers who entered would be met by long counters, rounded glass showcases, and side walls lined with shelves, drawers, and bins holding all manner of items for sale. Imagine the Johnsons and their neighbors coming to the store to purchase such necessities as flour, tools, lanterns, fabric, or shoes. Lucky children with a little spending money could select penny candies from glass jars. The shop keeper would cut, grind, or weigh merchandise that required it, wrap the purchases with brown paper and string from a roll at the end of the counter, and ring the total up on the cash register. The waiting customers could catch up on the latest local news or peruse the notices posted on the store wall.

W.E. "Bud" Withers and Warren and E.D. Spauldings operated the general store in Johnson City as a partnership from April 1909 until December 1915 when Withers bought out the Spauldings. He continued to run the business as W.E. Withers until 1925, first in the original frame building and then in the stone building which currently houses the Johnson City Bank.

The historic Withers & Spauldings General Store now serves as an exhibit area and information center for Johnson City. Visitors can learn about Johnson City shopping and dining options as well as additional attractions in the surrounding Hill Country community.

Staffed by Johnson City Chamber of Commerce members, the property is part of Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park and is managed by the National Park Service.
audioDescription:
Withers and Spauldings General Store. 509 words

This historic building is located on the southeast corner of Main Street and Lady Bird Lane. The vertical siding is painted a dark red. The shutters and doors are painted white. Along the front a vertical extension has white lettering that reads, "Withers and Spauldings General Merchants." A sign in front reads,

"Welcome Center. Chamber of Commerce, Exhibits and information."

From the Lady Bird Lane side, a set of five steps leads up to the board sidewalk which is covered by a roof on both sides of the building. Just to the right of the steps a ramp provides wheelchair access.

The entrance to the building is a pair of double doors on the corner. A bench sits along each wall on either side of the doors.

Near the steps on Lady Bird Lane is a tall vertical sign behind a glass front. Down the right side of the sign is an old photograph of a teenage boy dressed in a light-colored suit and a straw hat. The caption reads,

"Lyndon Baines Johnson, (nicknamed â€˜LBJ') at age 15, the year he graduated from high school. His family moved to Johnson City from the country west of here in 1913, when he was five years old."

At bottom right is a smaller photograph of the general store with the dirt street in front full of turkeys. Several people stand on the store porch and along the street behind the turkeys. One man at right is outlined in red. The caption reads,

"Johnson City was once a gathering point for turkeys raised by local farmers. In this 1913 photograph of Withers and Spauldings, the president's father is outlined in red."

Down the left side of the panel are two other photographs. One shows an old limestone building. The caption reads,

"The Johnson City Bank was formerly Withers Opera House, where plays - some written by Rebekah Baines Johnson, the president's mother - were performed."

The other photograph shows a small white house. The caption reads,

"The LBJ Boyhood Home is located on Elm Street, a short walk from Withers and Spauldings and just one block from the park visitor center."

At the bottom of the left side is a map showing the visitor center two blocks south of your current location with the Johnson Settlement area to the west and the Boyhood Home nearby.

Text at the top of the panel reads,

"Johnson City, A Presidential Home Town. Several buildings in town were built and owned by Lyndon Johnson's ancestor James Polk Johnson or owned by his father Sam E. Johnson, Jr, including the old grist mill building next o Withers and Spauldings. Lyndon Johnson also had a hand in getting a hospital, new post office and a subsidized housing development for his home town.

"Withers and Spaulings. This building served as a dry goods store; general merchandise emporium; cotton, wool and mohair warehouse; and a youth recreation center. It has been restored to its appearance about 1915-1920. President Johnson gave it to the American people in December 1972."

End of description.
